title: 103_s817
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Resource Efficient Building Materials Act of 1993" and includes definitions for various terms. The Act defines key terms such as "Administrator," "agency," "resource efficient materials," and "resource efficient building materials." The Act defines key terms such as "Administrator," "agency," "resource efficient materials," and "resource efficient building materials." The term "solid waste" and "construction" have specific definitions under the Solid Waste Disposal Act. Federal Acquisition and Use of Resource Efficient Building Materials is addressed in Section 3 of the Act. The Administrator will establish a 3-year pilot program to demonstrate the use of resource efficient building materials in Federal facilities. Selection criteria include conservation of natural resources, quality and durability similar to conventional materials, cost competitiveness, meeting environmental standards, and energy efficiency. The Administrator will give preference to resource efficient building materials that best satisfy energy efficiency standards. The Administrator will report to Congress on the pilot program's implementation, detailing the type and quantities of resource efficient building materials used, their cost and performance compared to conventional materials, potential expansion beyond the pilot program, and an assessment of how well the materials meet specified criteria. The Resource Efficient Building Material Advisory Board is established with 11 members appointed by the Administrator, including representatives from various agencies, the environmental community, construction industry, manufacturing companies, and scientific field. The Resource Efficient Building Material Advisory Board consists of 11 members appointed by the Administrator, including representatives from different sectors. The Board advises the Administrator on resource efficient building materials, makes recommendations on their use in Federal construction, and suggests ways to reduce solid waste generation. The Administrator serves as the Chairman of the Board, which meets quarterly. The Resource Efficient Building Material Advisory Board meets quarterly and follows the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The Administrator makes initial appointments within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The Board may hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use the United States mail. The Board may use the United States mail, accept gifts, and compensate members. Members not federal employees receive pay, while federal employees serve without additional compensation. The Board members are allowed travel expenses and per diem while performing services. The Chairman can appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. Compensation for staff can be set without adhering to certain provisions of the United States Code. The Board members can receive travel expenses and per diem. The Chairman can appoint an executive director and staff without following civil service laws. Compensation for staff can be set without adhering to certain provisions of the United States Code. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Board without reimbursement. The Chairman can procure temporary and intermittent services at specified rates. The Board will submit a report to Congress and the Administrator within 90 days of completing the demonstration program. The report will include recommendations for acquiring resource-efficient materials, reducing solid waste in Federal construction, evaluating the program's implementation, and any dissenting views. The Board will cease to exist within 1 year of submitting the report. SEC. 6. GUIDELINES TO FEDERAL AGENCIES. The Administrator must promulgate regulations with guidelines for Federal agencies on minimizing solid waste and maximizing resource efficient building materials in Federal building construction, including bid requirements and acceptable plan standards. The Administrator must consider recommendations from the Resource Efficient Building Material Advisory Board when implementing regulations for Federal agencies on minimizing solid waste and maximizing resource efficient building materials in Federal building construction. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 1994-1996: $5,000,000 for 1994, $7,000,000 for 1995, and $8,000,000 for 1996 to support the purposes of the Act.
